summary: Ukraine is experiencing a multifaceted crisis characterized by ongoing hostilities and significant humanitarian challenges. The Health Resources and Services Availability Monitoring System (HeRAMS) continues to monitor the status of health facilities and identify service gaps[79], while nuclear safety and security, particularly at the Zaporizhzhya Nuclear Power Plant (ZNPP), remain vulnerable with frequent external power outages and only one of four 750 kV power lines operational[28]. The country is still recovering from the Kakhovka Dam destruction a year prior, which resulted in devastating flooding, at least 15 deaths, damage to over 37,000 houses, and disrupted water supply for a million people[83]. Education activities in regions like Sumska, Donetska, and Kharkivska oblasts aim to restore normalcy for children amidst displacement and intensified missile attacks, with educational consultation points in Donetska oblast temporarily suspended and evacuations of families with children initiated in May 2024 due to worsening security[89][90]. Telecommunications infrastructure has also been severely affected, including a major cyberattack in December 2023 that disrupted mobile signals for millions, and temporary internet services were deployed in Odesa in May due to intensified shelling[49]. Economically, direct damage to Ukraine has reached USD 155 billion, with economic losses at USD 499 billion, and reconstruction efforts are estimated to cost over USD 486 billion[87]. Efforts are underway to address legal issues such as housing compensation[92]and provide mental health and psychosocial support to over 117,000 people[46], with calls for women's inclusive participation in reconstruction processes[5].

28.context: "Gender equality has received very little attention in the previous two Ukraine Recovery Conferences in Lugano in 2022 and in London in 2023. It has also been largely absent from the various recovery and reconstruction plans that have been formulated by donor governments and international organizations. But Ukrainian women's rights and women-led organizations continue to drive efforts to meet the needs of the most vulnerable groups and provide vital assistance to survivors of gender-based violence. They are advocating for the rights of women and girls and are essential to increase the participation of those groups in processes and decisions that affect them now and will continue to impact them after the war.
28.title: Ukraine Recovery Conference 2024 in Berlin: Time for Women to Lead in Recovery

46.context: However, the ZNPP is not currently planning to complete repairs, at this time, as the line itself remains unavailable due to damage sustained earlier in the conflict, away from the site. The ZNPP had four 750 kV lines available before the conflict, but only one is remaining.The IAEA experts were informed that western-supplied switchyard equipment, installed before the conflict, remained in good condition. The teams reported that nuclear safety and security is being maintained despite the effects of the ongoing conflict, including air raid alarms on several days over the past week.One reactor unit at each of the Rivne and the South Ukraine NPPs were in shutdown over the last week for planned maintenance and refuelling, while one other unit at the South Ukraine NPP is in planned outage.
46.title: Update 231 - IAEA Director General Statement on Situation in Ukraine

49.title: Recovering joyful childhood experiences for Ukraine's children in Moldova through art therapy

5.context: The ETC will deploy the network equipment in Kramatorsk once the security situation is improved there.From 07 to 08 May, in response to an urgent request from local authorities in Odesa, the ETC set up temporary internet connectivity services for registration points and tents in Odesa opened by the local authorities for support to people affected by intensified shelling. The ETC used its existing Remote Site on Vehicle RsoV and satellite solutions to deliver the service. In May, Ukraine's Kyivstar allocated US90 million to deal with the aftermath of the major cyberattack on telecommunications infrastructure that occurred in December 2023, which damaged infrastructure and disrupted mobile phone signals for millions of Ukrainians.ETC Activities CoordinationThe ETC coordinated two Telecommunications Security Standards TESS training sessions which took place from 13 to 17 May and from 20 to 24 May with 36 participants from 12 UN agencies. The objective of the training was to build capacity and provide in-depth induction into UN security communications systems SCS for technical UN personnel.

79.context: title: HeRAMS Ukraine verification snapshot: March 2024 ENUK  content: OverviewThe Health Resources and Services Availability Monitoring System HeRAMS aims to provide decision-makers and health stakeholders with vital, up-to-date information. This system is dedicated to monitoring the availability of critical health resources and services, thus playing a crucial role in identifying existing gaps and establishing intervention priorities.HeRAMS has been operational in Ukraine since November 2022. This current report provides a high-level summary of the up-to-date status of health facilities within Ukraine, focusing on the availability of essential services and the challenges impeding access to these services. A more comprehensive and in-depth version of this report can be accessed here English version, Ukrainian version.
79.title: HeRAMS Ukraine verification snapshot: March 2024 [EN/UK]

83.context: title: One year after the Kakhovka dam disaster, MSF continues to provide support ENUK  content: Project Update6 June 2024The Mdecins Sans Frontires MSF mobile clinic team is returning from the Kherson oblast region in southeastern Ukraine after an intense day of seeing patients. The road goes along the Inhulets river. Cows are grazing on the green slopes along the bank, and the fields are ripening, but the destroyed buildings in every village we pass and the Beware of mines' signs constantly remind us of the war.A year ago, one of the biggest disasters since the start of the full-scale war took place here in the southern part of Ukraine. At least 15 people died, 80 settlements were flooded, more than 37,000 houses were damaged, and the water supply system for a million people was destroyed when the Kakhovka hydroelectric power station dam was ruined in an explosion, according to the UN.Some of the territories flooded then are under Russian military occupation and the international community has been denied humanitarian access to them.
83.title: One year after the Kakhovka dam disaster, MSF continues to provide support [EN/UK]

87.context: title: Pragmatically Integrating Sustainability Into the Reconstruction of Ukraine  content: by Samuel Soman.IntroductionAccording to the latest estimates, direct damage to Ukraine in the 2 years since Russia's full- scale invasion has reached USD 155 billion, Kyiv School of Economics, 2024 with economic losses amounting to USD 499 billion World Bank, 2024. Considering an ambitious 10-year plan by the Ukrainian government and the international community, it will cost over USD 486 billion to fund reconstruction efforts World Bank, 2024. Although devastating, this juncture can be a watershed moment for Ukrainian society to "build back better. "Ukraine aims to capitalize upon its reconstruction to transform its economy and society to become climate resilient and inclusive.
87.title: Pragmatically Integrating Sustainability Into the Reconstruction of Ukraine

The number of requests for monetary compensation from owners of destroyed housing located in the temporarily occupied territory has increased, as they expect that the eRecovery program on destroyed housing will be expanded to the temporarily occupied territories. The Head of the Parliamentary Committee on the Organization of State Power, Local Self-Government, Regional Development and Urban Planning', Olena Shuliak, and the Deputy Prime Minister  Minister for Reintegration of Temporarily Occupied Territories, Iryna Vereshchuk, noted plans to expand this program to other temporarily occupied territories in the future, including Mariupol and Bakhmut. clusters.cluster_summary:
The ongoing conflict in Ukraine has placed significant stress on services and housing stock across virtually every Oblast, as the Government of Ukraine (GoU) regains control over regions previously under occupation and on the frontlines of war. These areas have seen their infrastructure and services severely affected, leading to increased demand and strain on available resources[1]. In particular, communities along the Inhulets River faced a shortage of drinking water due to flooding of all wells and boreholes[13][14]. To mitigate this, Doctors Without Borders (MSF) purchased and distributed large quantities of water and storage containers to residents, with volunteers assisting in transporting supplies across the river by boat[11][12][13].

In Sumy, the presence of only 11 Collective Centers (CCs) is insufficient to accommodate the potential influx of internally displaced persons (IDPs), especially if the security situation deteriorates within a 20-30 km zone[21]. This highlights the broader geographical challenges in Ukraine, where the nature of the crisis is geographically specific, necessitating different interventions based on the context. For instance, Context 1 involves areas regularly attacked that require emergency activities, while Context 4 includes regions not under government control, where humanitarian access is limited, markets are non-functional, and last-mile distribution is challenging[31][32][37].

To monitor and report the effectiveness of emergency construction materials and shelter kits (ECM and ESK) distribution, specific indicators are used, such as the number of households, individuals, social facilities, and residential units supported with emergency shelter assistance[42]. Meanwhile, the Ukraine Red Cross Society (URCS) has been actively involved in external coordination forums, notably attaining co-chair status in the Cash Working Group (CWG) through the leadership and training efforts of embedded CashCap experts[51][52]. This role has provided URCS with visibility among donors and international organizations, enhancing their legitimacy in Cash and Voucher Assistance (CVA)[54].

Despite these advancements, perceived gaps within URCS include a lack of full cash readiness, a gap in understanding at the branch level, and the absence of sectoral cash[61][74]. To address these issues, interviewees have advocated for structured deployment with clearer objectives and increased involvement in expert selection, proposing that the National Society (NS) and CashCap be directly involved in decision-making and Terms of Reference (ToRs) drafting[70]. CashCap experts have significantly enhanced CVA skills and competence in Ukraine through daily teaching, mentoring, and capacity-building activities, leading to substantial improvements in documentation and information management[71][73][74].

The Multi-sector Needs Assessment (MSNA) data underscores the multifaceted challenges faced by various demographic groups in Ukraine, emphasizing the need for targeted interventions. The assessment highlights that the intersection of head of household gender with other vulnerabilities exacerbates households' needs, covering aspects such as gender, disability, inclusion, displacement, and humanitarian needs[81][82]. This data is crucial for prioritizing assistance based on specific household and individual characteristics, such as female-headed households, disabled person-headed households, vulnerable older people, persons with disabilities, and children without caretaker or family support[81].

1.context: Services and housing stock, although functional, are under stress due to increased demand. This situation occurs in virtually every Oblast of the country. Context 3 pertains to areas where the Government of Ukraine GoU is regaining control. These are regions that have been under occupation and on the frontlines of war, where infrastructure and services have been severely affected.

Mr Madinger represented the results of the 2023 Multi-sector Needs Assessment MSNA based on 13,332 households' interviews, using mixed face-to-face and computer assisted telephone interviews.
82.title: Gender in Humanitarian Action (GiHA) Working Group, 14/05/2024 [Meeting Minutes] [EN/UK]

81.context: The limitation of the assessment: The MSNA may not have captured intra household dynamics, such as those that may exist between men, women, boys, and girls within a single household. This assessment highlights the multifaceted challenges faced by various demographic groups in Ukraine, emphasizing the need for targeted interventions addressing these diverse challenges. Findings demonstrate that while head of household gender is important, it is not the only factor driving needs. The intersection of head of household gender with other vulnerabilities, seem to aggravate households' level of need.

Efforts are underway to revitalize irrigation systems, which could significantly boost vegetable and fruit production, particularly in regions impacted by the Kakhovka Dam's destruction in 2023[1]. Despite these targeted activities, less attention is being given to the fruit and vegetable, dairy, poultry, and honey sectors[11][21]. The sources do not provide information on how the FAO is prioritizing resource allocation among these various agricultural sectors.

A major challenge facing Ukraine's agricultural sector is labor shortages, which are significantly curtailing production[31]. To address this issue, investments in adapting agricultural equipment for use by persons with disabilities (PWDs) are being considered. Such investments could not only help mitigate labor shortages but also reduce unemployment among PWDs[21][31].

Additionally, the destruction of infrastructure due to war presents another formidable challenge to agricultural production[41]. However, the sources do not clearly outline proposed solutions to specifically address the challenges arising from this destruction[41].

1.context: Among the solution examined are targeted activities to revitalize irrigation systems could increase vegetable and fruit production, especially in areas affected by the Kakhovka Dam's destruction in 2023. Local-level interventions focusing on transportation could prove beneficial, especially for household-level and smallholder producers, who are hardest hit by transport costs.

clusters.cluster_summary:
Following the destruction of the Kakhovka Dam in southern Ukraine, middle-aged and elderly populations have faced significant healthcare challenges, including limited access to quality medicine and mental health issues such as anxiety and sleep disturbances, compounded by chronic diseases[1][7]. The overall healthcare system in the region has been severely impacted, making healthcare access increasingly difficult[1]. In the Kherson and Mykolaiv regions, healthcare workers operate under dire conditions, with destroyed hospitals, a shortage of medical staff, and daily shelling[2][9][21][22].

Efforts to address these challenges include the work of Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF), which has provided medical and humanitarian aid, including operating mobile clinics in the Kherson oblast region[2][4][11][12]. MSF continues to support the affected populations one year after the disaster, addressing mental health issues like anxiety and sleep disturbances[11][12][20]. The mobile clinics, staffed by doctors, paramedics, nurses, social workers, and psychologists, offer medical services and medicines to residents in Kherson and Mykolaiv regions[45][50][71][80].

In the village of Virivka, Kherson, where the medical facility was destroyed and looted during the Russian military occupation, Ministry of Health nurse Olha Varenyk initially conducted medical check-ups in her home. A modular structure was later installed in her yard to facilitate patient consultations[21][22]. Despite the challenges, MSF mobile clinics continue to provide essential services, including checking blood pressure and blood sugar levels and prescribing necessary medicines[58]. In Novosofiyivka, Mykolaiv region, most patients at MSF clinics are elderly women with cardiovascular diseases, for which MSF health promoters provide education[51][54][58][60].

The humanitarian response also includes addressing a shortage of drinking water in communities along the Inhulets River, where wells and boreholes were flooded[63][64]. MSF purchased large quantities of water and storage containers, distributing them to residents with the help of volunteers who transported supplies by boat[61][62][71][75]. On the inaccessible side of the river, MSF was the sole organization offering medical services and medicines at that time[53][59][71][75].

The destruction of the Kakhovka hydroelectric power station and subsequent flooding have emotionally impacted residents, causing distress and forcing relocations to higher ground[41][42][43]. In response, MSF continues to operate mobile clinics, providing medical services and medicines, transporting patients to hospitals, and supporting frontline hospitals with medical donations[71][80].

The broader context of the conflict in Ukraine has led to significant civilian harm, with the UN documenting violations against Ukrainian children and verifying cases of harm, although the actual extent is likely higher due to limited access to affected areas[131][132][135]. More than 600 Ukrainian children have been killed, and 1,420 injured since the escalation of Russia's invasion in February 2022[137]. The UN works with the Government to provide necessary care, and over 117,000 people have benefited from mental health and psychosocial support services in Ukraine and neighboring countries[131][135].

In response to the ongoing conflict, the Health Resources and Services Availability Monitoring System (HeRAMS) monitors the availability of critical health resources and services in Ukraine, aiming to identify gaps and establish intervention priorities[121][122][128]. The system provides a summary of the status of health facilities, focusing on the availability of essential services and challenges impeding access[121].

Efforts to support displaced populations include the distribution of dignity kits and psychological first aid in Kharkiv, where the Gender-based Violence (GBV) team and Mental Health and Psychosocial Support (MPHSS) team provide essential services[151]. Additionally, Psychological First Aid training for faith and youth leaders in Lviv aims to foster resilience and mental well-being at the grassroots level[161][171].

In Donetska and Sumska oblasts, provisions for the wellbeing and education of evacuated children include access to online learning and safe spaces for wellbeing activities, with support for teachers facing increased challenges[191][192][193][195][205]. These efforts aim to mitigate potential learning losses and provide psychological assistance to children traumatized by the war[191][205].

9.context: Destroyed hospitals, a lack of medical staff, and daily shelling are the conditions under which healthcare workers in the Kherson and Mykolaiv oblasts work.Ministry of Health nurse Olha Varenyk shows a medical facility in the village of Virivka in Kherson oblast. 5.context: title: Kakhovka Dam destruction, one year on ENUK  content: One year ago today, the destruction of the Kakhovka Dam unleashed a devastating flooding that left over 620 square kilometres of the Ukrainian territory under water. This was possibly one of the most significant incidents of damage to civilian infrastructure since the start of the Russian invasion of Ukraine in February 2022. The destruction claimed lives, forced thousands to flee, left thousands more stranded and laid waste to Ukrainian land and livelihoods on both sides of the front line The Kakhovka reservoir, the primary source of drinking water for over 700,000 people in southern Ukraine, was depleted. The catastrophic environmental effects of the flooding will linger for years to come, affecting not only Ukraine.The UN responseThe UN response was swift and continues today.
5.title: Kakhovka Dam destruction, one year on [EN/UK]

4.context: title: One year after Ukraine's Kakhovka dam disaster  content: The destruction of the Kakhovka dam in Ukraine last June devastated communities, cutting off the water supply to one million people and making health care harder to access.After the dam at Kakhovka Hydroelectric Power Plant in Ukraine's Kherson region was destroyed on June 6, 2023, Doctors Without BordersMdecins Sans Frontires MSF teams provided medical and humanitarian aid to people affected. One year after the tragedy, communities are still trying to cope with the consequences, including mental health effects such as anxiety and sleep disturbances.On the banks of the Inhulets River in the Kherson region of Ukraine, cows graze on greenery beside ripened fields. The idyllic scene is interrupted, however, by the sight of destroyed buildings and "Beware of mines" signsreminders of the ongoing war.A year ago, this part of southern Ukraine suffered one of its biggest disasters since the start of the full-scale war when the Kakhovka Hydroelectric Power Station dam was destroyed, killing 15 people.
4.title: One year after Ukraine’s Kakhovka dam disaster

11.context: title: One year after the Kakhovka dam disaster, MSF continues to provide support ENUK  content: Project Update6 June 2024The Mdecins Sans Frontires MSF mobile clinic team is returning from the Kherson oblast region in southeastern Ukraine after an intense day of seeing patients. The road goes along the Inhulets river. Cows are grazing on the green slopes along the bank, and the fields are ripening, but the destroyed buildings in every village we pass and the Beware of mines' signs constantly remind us of the war.A year ago, one of the biggest disasters since the start of the full-scale war took place here in the southern part of Ukraine. At least 15 people died, 80 settlements were flooded, more than 37,000 houses were damaged, and the water supply system for a million people was destroyed when the Kakhovka hydroelectric power station dam was ruined in an explosion, according to the UN.Some of the territories flooded then are under Russian military occupation and the international community has been denied humanitarian access to them.
11.title: One year after the Kakhovka dam disaster, MSF continues to provide support [EN/UK]

42.context: "We were delivering medicines by boat"The Inhulets is a tributary of the Dnipro River that flows through three oblasts: Dnipro, Mykolaiv, and Kherson. After the destruction of the Kakhovka hydroelectric power station on the night of 6 June 2023, 18 cubic kilometres of water poured into the Dnipro within three to four days, leading to a significant rise in the water level in the river and its tributaries, including the Inhulets.MSF medical activity manager Vladyslav Butskyi remembers that day well. Then, he worked as a doctor in one of our mobile clinics. "In the morning, as usual, we went to Snihurivka in the Mykolaiv region," says Butskyi.

91.context: Eight HALO minefields in the neighbouring Mykolaiv region located along the Inhulets river were severely impacted by the floods. One of the most pressing issues was the displacement of UXO, a grim legacy of the ongoing conflict in Ukraine. These deadly remnants of war were displaced by the powerful currents and carried to new, often unpredictable locations.BELOW THE SURFACE OF THE WATERSome areas where HALO teams had been working in Mykolaiv oblast were severely impacted by the flooding which potentially contained new explosive threats. As a result, operations in the affected areas ceased for up to six months.
91.title: One Year Since the Kakhovka Dam Destruction

101.context: title: Ukraine Cash and Voucher Health Framework 1.0 MAY 2024  content: Health Cluster partners International Rescue Committe IRC and Stellar Ukraine mobile teams receiving displaced people for health consultations at the Kharkiv City Transit Center. Of these, 3.8 million people were targeted for assistance in the southern, eastern, and northern oblasts bordering the front line. Along with service delivery, and the procurement and distribution of medicines and supplies, cash and voucher assistance has been one of the accepted modalities of providing health assistance by health partners as stated in the HNRP.Since the launch of the HNRP in December 2023, air strikes have intensified in areas nearest the frontline and those bordering the Russian Federation. As of January 2024 the humanitarian crisis in Ukraine has worsened significantly.
101.title: Ukraine Cash and Voucher Health Framework 1.0 MAY 2024

112.context: title: HeRAMS Ukraine verification snapshot: January - April 2024 ENUK  content: DisclaimerIt is important to note that the deployment of HeRAMS is ongoing, including data verification and validation. Hence, this analysis is not final and was produced solely for the purpose of informing operations.MethodologyThe Health Resources and Services Availability Monitoring System HeRAMS is a system dedicated to monitoring the availability of critical health resources and services, thus playing a crucial role in identifying existing gaps and establishing intervention priorities. HeRAMS aims to provide decision-makers and health stakeholders with vital, up-to-date information.HeRAMS was launched in Ukraine by the World Health Organization WHO Country Office in Ukraine and the Ministry of Health MOH in November 2022. Since its initiation, data has been consistently collected and updated by designated representatives at both the Departments of Health and health facility levels, focusing on all public health facilities that are accessible1 .Acknowledging potential factors that might compromise data quality, the HeRAMS team at WHO CO opted to undertake data verification.
112.title: HeRAMS Ukraine verification snapshot: January - April 2024 [EN/UK]

111.context: title: HeRAMS Ukraine verification snapshot: March 2024 ENUK  content: OverviewThe Health Resources and Services Availability Monitoring System HeRAMS aims to provide decision-makers and health stakeholders with vital, up-to-date information. This system is dedicated to monitoring the availability of critical health resources and services, thus playing a crucial role in identifying existing gaps and establishing intervention priorities.HeRAMS has been operational in Ukraine since November 2022. This current report provides a high-level summary of the up-to-date status of health facilities within Ukraine, focusing on the availability of essential services and the challenges impeding access to these services. A more comprehensive and in-depth version of this report can be accessed here English version, Ukrainian version.

134.context: title: War must never be normalized for child victims: Humanitarian Coordinator in Ukraine  content: In remarks to commemorate the International Day of Innocent Children Victims of Aggression , Denise Brown also noted that boys and girls in frontline regions have had to spend the equivalent of seven months underground in bomb shelters because of relentless attacks.Tweet URL UNUkraine"I will not stop repeating that the entire international community must never accept as normal what is happening in Ukraine. Children should not grow up in the middle of a war," she said. "War is not normal, and we must not get used to it. Brown said she has met many lovely, joyful and smiling children during her time in Ukraine, adding that despite the full-scale Russian invasion more than two years ago, they still feel loved and protected.She recalled a visit last Christmas to rural Hroza, located in the Kharkiv region, where she shared chocolate and candies with local children who told her of their dreams to become a doctor or teacher someday.
134.title: War must never be normalized for child victims: Humanitarian Coordinator in Ukraine

All sources and information are assessed for their relevance and credibility and cross-checked against other information.

131.context: Brown said Russia has approved and ratified the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child , "but the truth is that they are blatantly disregarding what they committed to. And it is for this reason that the Secretary-General officially listed Russia for the killing and maiming of Ukrainian children in 2023. "She upheld the UN's commitment to support the people of Ukraine whose lives have been torn apart by the war, adding that the UN consistently documents these violations and works with the Government to provide the care these children so desperately need. "I know this will not alleviate the suffering of families and will never compensate for the lives lost or the grief endured," she said.
131.title: War must never be normalized for child victims: Humanitarian Coordinator in Ukraine

151.context: Even as we carry out our relief activities, we continue to assess and respond to people's needs.Our Gender-based Violence GBV team in Kharkiv distributed 197 dignity kits there this week to women and girls evacuated from around Vovchansk and Lyptsi. At the same time, a psychologist from our Mental Health and Psychosocial Support MPHSS team was on hand to assess needs and offer psychological first aidproviding support to 43 people. On June 4, the GBV team also distributed 18 dignity kits at a collective center housing some of the IDPs. There, our colleagues told the women and girls about the psychosocial support and other services available to them, and invited them to visit our women's and girls' safe space in Kharkiv.Meanwhile, the International Medical Corps psychologist also assessed needs and offered support to displaced people at a Kharkiv dormitory on Molochna Street.
151.title: Ukraine: Kharkiv Emergency Situation Report #2 June 5, 2024

161.context: title: 33 faith and youth leaders in Ukraine undergo final session on Psychological First Aid  content: Lviv, Ukraine - Thirty-three Ukrainian faith leaders are taking part in the final five-day training on Psychological First Aid in Lviv, Ukraine, led by Aladin Borja, World Vision's Mental Health and Psychosocial Support Technical Advisor. By equipping faith leaders, youth leaders, and volunteers with practical skills in social and emotional learning, they can provide the needed support to traumatized individuals.Upon returning to their communities, these leaders will apply the learned psychological interventions to train and support those most affected by the war, fostering resilience and mental well-being at the grassroots level.Story by Communications Manager Laurentia Jora I Photos by Communications Officer Oleksandr Sphygunov

186.context: They are often surprised at the very low number of regular schools that integrate children with disability in Slovakia".8 As the Platform further reported, "families may not disclose their child's diagnosis in order to facilitate their enrollment in school or their integration in the wider society". Additional information provided by the study presented important concerns frequently cited by parents regarding lack of disability-adapted early childhood and formal education capacities. In addition, bullying remains an important concern raised by parents of children with disabilities. In general, HH with no person with a disability reported being more aware of protection services mainly state social services, than those with a member with disability.
186.title: MULTI - SECTOR NEEDS ASSESSMENT ANNEX REPORT | PERSONS WITH DISABILITIES

182.context: According to the analysis, "the government together with international and community-level organizations should address the informational barrier that carers face in access to healthcare, education, social benefits, etc. In an often-changing legislative environment, working on periodic and timely informational campaigns that target not only Ukrainian carers but also local practitioners and social workers assisting this demographic is crucial in making the already available services more accessible. ".13With regards to awareness of available services to reach out to and the possibility to report cases of violence against children in the community, HH with a person with disability reported higher awareness on those services, between 97 and 99, compared to HH without a person with disability 95. In addition, between 69 and 73 of HH with a person with disability reported awareness on how to access gender-based violence services available in Slovakia, compared to the 73 reported by HH without a person with disabilities.Economic vulnerability  livelihoodsOverall, persons with disability reported lower education level in comparison to those with no reported disability; higher percentage was obtained on secondary and vocational education on individuals with disability, and master's degree was more cited by persons with no disability.
182.title: MULTI - SECTOR NEEDS ASSESSMENT ANNEX REPORT | PERSONS WITH DISABILITIES

Among the total number of HH with at least one member with disability 295, only between 14 and 17 of HH reported not having received any assistance in the last 3 months11. In terms of satisfaction, HH with a person with disability presents higher satisfaction levels, between 74 and 76, and only between 6 and 8 of households with a member with disability reported dissatisfaction with the assistance received.

194.context: As of 23 May 2024, The Head of the Donetsk Regional State Administration and the Head of the Regional Military Administration, Vadym Filashkin, announced that due to the worsening security situation in the region, the operation of educational consultation points for schoolchildren is temporarily suspended. Any gathering of people, especially children, could pose a threat to their lives. As of 29 May 2024, the regional commission on technogenic and environmental safety and emergencies in Donetska oblast has decided to evacuate families with children from Lyman, the villages of Lypove, Nove, Karpivka, Stavky of the Lymanska hromada, the village of Prohres of the Hrodivska hromada, and the settlement of Zoria of the Illinivska hromada. The decision must be coordinated with the Coordination Headquarters for the mandatory evacuation of the population under martial law conditions.
194.title: PEOPLE IN NEED 11,663

clusters.cluster_summary:
In Lviv, Ukraine, the sustainability and effectiveness of Psychological First Aid training for faith and youth leaders are ensured as these leaders apply the learned psychological interventions upon returning to their communities. They use these interventions to train and support those most affected by the war, fostering resilience and mental well-being at the grassroots level[1]. Meanwhile, in Kharkivska oblast, efforts are underway to protect children's right to education amid disruptions caused by missile attacks and infrastructure damage. Education Cluster activities focus on supporting access to learning and wellbeing activities for children in safe spaces, especially when online education is disrupted by increased missile attacks and damages to civil infrastructure, including electricity and internet cuts[11][14][15][18].

Key measures include supporting access to wellbeing and learning in safe spaces[17], providing learning for school-age evacuees[18], and facilitating offline learning and wellbeing activities for both displaced and host community children to ensure they keep up with formal schooling and minimize learning losses[11]. Teachers affected by escalations, displacement, increased workload, and challenges in supporting their students receive support, including wellbeing services[11][21]. Specific activities include the provision of Mental Health and Psychosocial Support (MHPSS) for children, distribution of learning kits and electronic devices, establishment of safe spaces like Temporary Learning Spaces and Digital Learning Centers, and catch-up learning support services[11].

In Donetska oblast, as of May 29, 2024, the regional commission on technogenic and environmental safety and emergencies decided to evacuate families with children from specific areas, coordinating with the Coordination Headquarters for mandatory evacuation under martial law conditions. Military administration heads are tasked with pre-determining evacuation routes and transit hub availability[41][44]. Provisions for evacuated children include wellbeing and educational support in safe spaces, access to online learning amid intensified missile attacks, and offline learning and wellbeing activities when security allows, to engage with formal schooling and mitigate learning losses[42][43][45]. Teachers also receive support to manage escalations, displacement, and increased workloads[42][48]. There is a noted need for psychological assistance and rest for children traumatized by the war[41].

In Sumska oblast, tailored wellbeing and educational support services meet the needs of displaced children by providing support in safe spaces, ensuring access to online learning amidst intensified missile attacks, and facilitating offline learning and wellbeing activities when security permits[51][52][55][57]. Teachers facing similar challenges as those in other regions receive support to manage their increased workload and displacement[53][55]. Access to offline learning and wellbeing activities is contingent on the security situation, though specific criteria for determining this are not detailed[62][63].

By equipping faith leaders, youth leaders, and volunteers with practical skills in social and emotional learning, they can provide the needed support to traumatized individuals.Upon returning to their communities, these leaders will apply the learned psychological interventions to train and support those most affected by the war, fostering resilience and mental well-being at the grassroots level.Story by Communications Manager Laurentia Jora I Photos by Communications Officer Oleksandr Sphygunov

clusters.cluster_summary:
Organizations such as CARE and JurFem are actively advocating for gender equality and the rights of gender-based violence survivors in Ukraine's recovery efforts. They emphasize the importance of including Ukrainian women in decision-making processes and promoting gender equality throughout all reconstruction and recovery initiatives[1]. CARE highlights that the meaningful and direct participation of women, girls, and marginalized groups is essential to developing an equitable, inclusive, gender-responsive, and effective recovery agenda. They also stress the need to protect and ensure equitable access to services and opportunities for women to rebuild their lives[4].

At the Ukraine Recovery Conference 2024, CARE supports the broader participation of Ukrainian civil society, including women's rights and women-led organizations, and aims to integrate gender perspectives throughout the conference[3][12]. This participation is intended to ensure that economic support and inclusion in social programs for survivors are considered in discussions, decisions, and interventions[3]. JurFem, a partner organization of CARE, focuses on developing gender-oriented approaches in government and business, particularly in combating violence against women. Its Chairwoman, Khrystyna Kit, asserts that a just recovery is impossible without a gender component, emphasizing the need to strengthen the rights of gender-based violence survivors beyond just psychological and medical support[2].

The Multi-sector Needs Assessment (MSNA) data underscores the multifaceted challenges faced by various demographic groups in Ukraine, highlighting the necessity for targeted interventions. The assessment reveals that the intersection of head of household gender with other vulnerabilities exacerbates households' needs. It covers aspects such as gender, disability, inclusion, displacement, and humanitarian needs, and can be used to prioritize assistance for specific groups, including female-headed households, disabled person-headed households, vulnerable older people, persons with disabilities, and children without caretaker or family support[21][22].

In Kharkiv, the Gender-based Violence (GBV) team distributed 197 dignity kits to women and girls evacuated from areas like Vovchansk and Lyptsi. On June 4, an additional 18 dignity kits were distributed at a collective center for internally displaced persons (IDPs)[31]. A psychologist from the Mental Health and Psychosocial Support (MPHSS) team assessed needs and provided psychological first aid to 43 people, while informing women and girls about available psychosocial support and inviting them to visit a women's and girls' safe space in Kharkiv. An International Medical Corps psychologist also assessed needs and offered support to displaced people at a Kharkiv dormitory[31]. However, the immediate and long-term impacts of these specific interventions in Kharkiv remain unclear, and there is no information on how these interventions can be scaled to other affected areas in Ukraine.

4.context: title: Ukraine Recovery Conference 2024 in Berlin: Time for Women to Lead in Recovery  content: Bonn, June 7, 2024  In anticipation of the Ukraine Recovery Conference 2024 in Berlin on June 11 and 12, the international humanitarian organization CARE continues to call for all reconstruction and recovery processes to ensure the participation of Ukrainian women and to promote gender equality. So far, the priorities and needs of women have hardly been considered in the discussions on reconstruction. "The meaningful and direct participation of women, girls and marginalized groups in all decision-making processes is key to forming a recovery agenda that is equitable, inclusive, gender-responsive, and truly effective," says Franziska Jrns, CARE Ukraine Deputy Country Director. "We need to protect and ensure equitable access to services they need and opportunities to rebuild their lives.
4.title: Ukraine Recovery Conference 2024 in Berlin: Time for Women to Lead in Recovery

In the wake of the Kakhovka Dam's destruction on June 6, 2023, in Ukraine's Kherson region, targeted activities to revitalize irrigation systems are being examined to boost vegetable and fruit production, particularly in the affected areas[1]. This disaster prompted a significant humanitarian response, with Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) providing medical and humanitarian aid to those impacted[12]. One year later, MSF continues its support, operating a mobile clinic in the Kherson oblast region in southeastern Ukraine, where they see patients and address ongoing mental health issues such as anxiety and sleep disturbances, exacerbated by the reminders of war, including destroyed buildings and "Beware of mines" signs[11][12][20].

The destruction of the dam also led to a severe shortage of drinking water in the flooded areas of Kherson and Mykolaiv regions, as wells and boreholes were inundated[21][24]. To mitigate this, MSF purchased large quantities of water and storage containers, distributing them to residents[24][28]. They also provided packs with water and water disinfectants, which residents transported by boat to the other side[25][28]. Similarly, communities along the Inhulets River faced a drinking water shortage due to flooded wells and boreholes[33][34]. MSF addressed this by distributing water and storage containers[31][33]. The challenge of reaching the opposite bank of the Inhulets River was overcome with the help of volunteers, who assisted in transporting water, water disinfectants, and medicine kits by boat[31][32].

1.context: Among the solution examined are targeted activities to revitalize irrigation systems could increase vegetable and fruit production, especially in areas affected by the Kakhovka Dam's destruction in 2023. Local-level interventions focusing on transportation could prove beneficial, especially for household-level and smallholder producers, who are hardest hit by transport costs.
1.title: Farmers in Wartime: Promoting Adaptability and Resilience for Agriculture in Ukraine

Most of them are middle-aged and elderly people with chronic diseases. I have observed a change in their mental state after the events: anxiety and sleep disturbances.

12.context: title: One year after Ukraine's Kakhovka dam disaster  content: The destruction of the Kakhovka dam in Ukraine last June devastated communities, cutting off the water supply to one million people and making health care harder to access.After the dam at Kakhovka Hydroelectric Power Plant in Ukraine's Kherson region was destroyed on June 6, 2023, Doctors Without BordersMdecins Sans Frontires MSF teams provided medical and humanitarian aid to people affected. One year after the tragedy, communities are still trying to cope with the consequences, including mental health effects such as anxiety and sleep disturbances.On the banks of the Inhulets River in the Kherson region of Ukraine, cows graze on greenery beside ripened fields. The idyllic scene is interrupted, however, by the sight of destroyed buildings and "Beware of mines" signsreminders of the ongoing war.A year ago, this part of southern Ukraine suffered one of its biggest disasters since the start of the full-scale war when the Kakhovka Hydroelectric Power Station dam was destroyed, killing 15 people.
12.title: One year after Ukraine’s Kakhovka dam disaster

11.context: title: One year after the Kakhovka dam disaster, MSF continues to provide support ENUK  content: Project Update6 June 2024The Mdecins Sans Frontires MSF mobile clinic team is returning from the Kherson oblast region in southeastern Ukraine after an intense day of seeing patients. The road goes along the Inhulets river. Cows are grazing on the green slopes along the bank, and the fields are ripening, but the destroyed buildings in every village we pass and the Beware of mines' signs constantly remind us of the war.A year ago, one of the biggest disasters since the start of the full-scale war took place here in the southern part of Ukraine. At least 15 people died, 80 settlements were flooded, more than 37,000 houses were damaged, and the water supply system for a million people was destroyed when the Kakhovka hydroelectric power station dam was ruined in an explosion, according to the UN.Some of the territories flooded then are under Russian military occupation and the international community has been denied humanitarian access to them.
11.title: One year after the Kakhovka dam disaster, MSF continues to provide support [EN/UK]

clusters.cluster_summary:
The Zaporizhzhya Nuclear Power Plant (ZNPP) is currently facing significant challenges with its power lines and external power situation, which have been severely impacted by the ongoing conflict. This has led to repeated losses of connections to all its power lines, making the external power situation extremely vulnerable and prone to frequent outages[1]. Before the conflict, ZNPP had four 750 kV lines available, but now only one remains, and it is unavailable due to damage sustained earlier in the conflict, away from the site[2]. Despite these challenges, the ZNPP is not planning to complete repairs at this time[2].

The operational issues at the plant are compounded by the potential seriousness of a loss of off-site power, which could lead to higher nuclear fuel temperatures for reactors in operation in Ukraine[1]. Director General Grossi has emphasized that the ZNPP will not be restarted as long as nuclear safety and security remain in jeopardy due to the conflict[1]. Nevertheless, IAEA experts have been informed that nuclear safety and security are being maintained despite the ongoing conflict[2].

In response to Ukraine's requests, the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) is providing technical support and assistance to help re-establish a sound nuclear safety and security regime at Ukraine's nuclear facilities and in activities involving radioactive sources[11]. The report highlights the progress made by the Agency in these efforts, although it does not detail the specific technical support and assistance provided[11].

2.context: However, the ZNPP is not currently planning to complete repairs, at this time, as the line itself remains unavailable due to damage sustained earlier in the conflict, away from the site. The ZNPP had four 750 kV lines available before the conflict, but only one is remaining.The IAEA experts were informed that western-supplied switchyard equipment, installed before the conflict, remained in good condition. The teams reported that nuclear safety and security is being maintained despite the effects of the ongoing conflict, including air raid alarms on several days over the past week.One reactor unit at each of the Rivne and the South Ukraine NPPs were in shutdown over the last week for planned maintenance and refuelling, while one other unit at the South Ukraine NPP is in planned outage.
2.title: Update 231 - IAEA Director General Statement on Situation in Ukraine

1.context: However, Ukraine's electricity grid has been severely impacted by the conflict, with the ZNPP repeatedly losing connections to all its power lines. "For the Zaporizhzhya Nuclear Power Plant in particular, the external power situation remains extremely vulnerable, prone to frequent outages. But it is also a wider concern in the current circumstances, where a loss of off-site power event has the potential to be even more serious given the higher nuclear fuel temperatures for reactors in operation in Ukraine. We are continuing to follow the situation very closely in this regard, as I also informed Minister Galushchenko in today's meeting," Director General Grossi said.Director General Grossi, who had met with Rosatom head Alexey Likhachev in the Russian city of Kaliningrad last week, reiterated to Ukraine's energy minister that there was an understanding that the ZNPP would not be re-started as long as nuclear safety and security remained in jeopardy due to the conflict.
1.title: Update 231 - IAEA Director General Statement on Situation in Ukraine

11.context: title: Nuclear Safety, Security and Safeguards in Ukraine - Report by the Director General GOV20249  content: Summary The Board of Governors, in its resolutions GOV202217, GOV202258 and GOV202271, requested the Director General to continue to closely monitor the situation regarding nuclear safety, security and safeguards in Ukraine and regularly report formally to the Board of Governors on these matters. This report provides a summary of the situation in Ukraine regarding nuclear safety, security and safeguards. It covers the period from 15 November 2023 to 23 February 2024 and is based on information made available to the Agency, and verified by the Agency, during this period. This report covers the progress made by the Agency in responding to Ukraine's requests to provide technical support and assistance in re-establishing, as appropriate, a sound nuclear safety and security regime at its nuclear facilities and in activities involving radioactive sources.
11.title: Nuclear Safety, Security and Safeguards in Ukraine - Report by the Director General (GOV/2024/9)

clusters.cluster_id: SDG 8 - Decent Work and Economic Growth
clusters.cluster_summary:
In Ukraine, the agricultural sector faces significant challenges, particularly in the fruit and vegetable, dairy, poultry, and honey sectors, which receive less attention compared to others[1]. A major issue is labor shortages, which significantly curtail production across these sectors[11]. To address this, investments in adapting agricultural equipment for use by persons with disabilities (PWDs) could not only mitigate these shortages but also reduce unemployment among PWDs, providing a dual benefit to the economy and society[1][11].

In parallel, the Ukraine Red Cross Society (URCS) has been working to enhance its capabilities in Cash and Voucher Assistance (CVA). Despite some interviewees expressing concerns about the URCS's readiness, particularly at the branch level and the lack of sectoral cash, significant progress has been made[24]. CashCap experts have played a pivotal role in this transformation by enhancing CVA skills and competence through documentation development, information management improvements, and comprehensive training programs[23][24]. These efforts included daily teaching, mentoring, collective capacity-building activities, and providing quality feedback and reporting, which have collectively strengthened the URCS's capabilities[21]. As a result, the URCS has achieved co-chair status in the Cash Working Group (CWG), a testament to the experts' leadership and extensive experience in cash coordination[29][23].

Additionally, support is being extended to teachers in the Kharkivska oblast, who are dealing with the repercussions of escalations and displacement. These educators face increased workloads and challenges in supporting their students, and to assist them, wellbeing support services are being provided[31]. This comprehensive approach aims to address both the immediate and long-term needs of various sectors in Ukraine, fostering resilience and capacity building across the board.

1.context: Less attention, however, is paid to other sectors. Particularly, the fruit and vegetable, dairy, poultry, and honey sectors. Among the findings, are the impact of labour shortages as a significant factor curtailing production. Investments to adapt agricultural equipment for use by persons with disabilities PWDs could mitigate these shortages and lower unemployment among PWDs.The destruction of infrastructure being another challenging factor for production in the wake of war.
1.title: Farmers in Wartime: Promoting Adaptability and Resilience for Agriculture in Ukraine

clusters.cluster_summary:
The number of requests for technical documentation and cadastral numbers for plots of land designated for horticulture has surged, prompting legislative amendments to the Law on land plots allocation. These amendments, which have been passed in parliament and are awaiting the Presidential signature, extend the deadline for registering land ownership from January 1, 2025, to January 1, 2028. This extension aims to alleviate the backlog by providing owners and heirs more time to register their land, preventing it from being considered free and sold by the state if not registered by the earlier deadline [1][2][6].

In response to an urgent request from local authorities in Odesa due to intensified shelling, the Emergency Telecommunications Cluster (ETC) set up temporary internet connectivity services from May 7 to 8. These services supported registration points and tents opened by local authorities to assist affected individuals. The ETC utilized its existing Remote Site on Vehicle (RSoV) and satellite solutions to deliver the service, and by May 9, all community members were registered using the new network, concluding the ETC service [11][12][13][15].

The Zaporizhzhya Nuclear Power Plant (ZNPP) is facing significant challenges with its power lines and external power situation. The plant's electricity grid has been severely impacted by the conflict, leading to repeated losses of connections to all its power lines. Before the conflict, ZNPP had four 750 kV lines available, but only one remains, which is currently unavailable due to damage sustained earlier in the conflict, away from the site. Despite these challenges, IAEA experts were informed that nuclear safety and security are being maintained, although the ZNPP will not be re-started as long as these remain in jeopardy [31][32].

In the village of Virivka in Kherson, where the medical facility was destroyed and looted during Russian military occupation, Ministry of Health nurse Olha Varenyk initially conducted medical check-ups in her home. Recently, a modular structure was installed in her yard, allowing her to see patients there. Healthcare workers in the Kherson and Mykolaiv regions generally operate amid poor conditions, including destroyed hospitals, a lack of medical staff, and daily shelling [51][52].

The agricultural sector in Ukraine faces labor shortages that curtail production, particularly in the fruit and vegetable, dairy, poultry, and honey sectors. Investments to adapt agricultural equipment for use by persons with disabilities (PWDs) could mitigate these shortages and lower unemployment among PWDs. Additionally, targeted activities to revitalize irrigation systems are being examined to increase vegetable and fruit production, especially in areas affected by the Kakhovka Dam's destruction in 2023 [41][71][81].

Ukraine aims to capitalize on its reconstruction, estimated to cost over USD 486 billion, to transform its economy and society to become climate resilient and inclusive. The country can contribute to Europe's economic growth and strategic autonomy through innovation, energy security, decarbonization, and diversified supply chains [101][103].

To ensure the continuity of education for children in Kharkivska oblast amid disruptions caused by missile attacks and infrastructure damage, Education Cluster activities aim to protect children's right to education. Key response activities support access to learning and wellbeing activities for children in safe spaces, especially when their online education might be disrupted by increased missile attacks and damages to civil infrastructure, including electricity and internet cuts. Specific activities include the provision of Mental Health and Psychosocial Support (MHPSS) for children, distribution of learning kits and electronic devices, establishment of safe spaces for learning, and wellbeing support services for teachers [131][134][135][137][138].

At the same time, the legislator initiated amendments to this Law, extending the deadline for registration of land ownership until 1 January 2028. Amendments were passed in the parliament and await the Presidential signature.

2.context: It is common for notaries to refuse to open an inheritance case about property located in the temporarily occupied territory, likely due to the potential legal responsibility for such actions which would lie with the respective notary. The problem most often arises with private notaries, which have more discretion than state notaries, in particular in Vinnytsia Oblasts and in Kryvyi Rih City. As a result, the applicants heirs are forced to apply to the court to confirm ownership in the order of inheritance, paying a court fee and bearing the burden of proof. The number of requests for technical documentation and cadastral numbers for plots of land for horticulture has increased rapidly.

111.context: title: Nuclear Safety, Security and Safeguards in Ukraine - Report by the Director General GOV20249  content: Summary The Board of Governors, in its resolutions GOV202217, GOV202258 and GOV202271, requested the Director General to continue to closely monitor the situation regarding nuclear safety, security and safeguards in Ukraine and regularly report formally to the Board of Governors on these matters. This report provides a summary of the situation in Ukraine regarding nuclear safety, security and safeguards. It covers the period from 15 November 2023 to 23 February 2024 and is based on information made available to the Agency, and verified by the Agency, during this period. This report covers the progress made by the Agency in responding to Ukraine's requests to provide technical support and assistance in re-establishing, as appropriate, a sound nuclear safety and security regime at its nuclear facilities and in activities involving radioactive sources.

clusters.cluster_summary:
Labor shortages significantly impact Ukraine's agricultural sector, and adapting agricultural equipment for use by persons with disabilities (PWDs) could help mitigate these shortages while reducing unemployment among PWDs[1]. Meanwhile, the Ukraine Red Cross Society (URCS) has been actively involved in external coordination forums, notably Cash Working Groups (CWGs), where the embedding of CashCap experts has been instrumental. These experts have facilitated URCS's attainment of co-chair status in the CWG, enhancing their visibility among donors and international organizations and granting them legitimacy in Cash and Voucher Assistance (CVA)[11][12][14]. However, challenges remain, as URCS is perceived as not fully cash ready, with gaps in understanding at the branch level and a lack of sectoral cash[21][34].

To address these gaps, interviewees have advocated for structured deployments with clearer objectives and increased involvement in expert selection[30]. Proposals include involving the National Society (NS) and CashCap directly in decision-making and drafting Terms of Reference (ToRs), along with regular partner check-ins[30]. CashCap experts have significantly enhanced CVA skills and competence in Ukraine through daily teaching, mentoring, and capacity-building activities, leading to substantial improvements in documentation and information management[31][33][34]. Their leadership and training efforts have been crucial in URCS's co-chair status in the CWG[39].

The Multi-sector Needs Assessment (MSNA) data highlights the multifaceted challenges faced by various demographic groups in Ukraine, emphasizing the need for targeted interventions. The assessment covers gender, disability, inclusion, displacement, and humanitarian needs, showing that the intersection of head of household gender with other vulnerabilities exacerbates households' needs[41][42]. This data can prioritize assistance based on specific household and individual characteristics, such as female-headed households, disabled person-headed households, vulnerable older people, persons with disabilities, and children without caretaker or family support[41].

Households without a person with a disability generally reported greater awareness of protection services, primarily state social services, than those with a member with a disability[56]. However, households with a person with a disability reported higher awareness of services for reporting violence against children and slightly higher awareness of psychosocial support services[51]. Awareness of gender-based violence services in Slovakia was slightly lower among households with a person with a disability compared to those without[52].

In Sumska oblast, wellbeing and educational support services are tailored to meet the needs of displaced children. These services provide safe spaces for wellbeing and educational support, ensure access to online learning amidst missile attacks, and facilitate offline learning and wellbeing activities when security permits[61][62][65][67]. Additionally, support is extended to teachers who may be displaced or face increased workloads due to escalations, helping them support their students effectively[63][65].

63.context: Education Cluster activities in Kharkivska oblast aim at ensuring protecting children's wellbeing in the face of displacement, whilst ensuring children's right to education is protected amid the disruptions caused by the recent escalation of hostilities. clusters.cluster_summary:
Owners of destroyed housing in temporarily occupied territories of Ukraine face significant legal challenges that hinder their ability to receive compensation through the eRecovery program. A primary issue is the difficulty in property registration, as most Bureaus of Technical Inventory (BTIs) in these areas were not relocated to government-controlled territories and have been damaged, destroyed, or looted. This situation makes it nearly impossible to obtain the necessary information for state registration of property rights (SRPR), which is a precondition for applying for compensation through the eRecovery program[3][5][6][31][32][34]. Owners who acquired property before 2013 face additional hurdles, as they often need to undergo a judicial procedure to recognize their ownership, incurring court fees and bearing the burden of proof[3][4][6][8][34].

Inheritance issues further complicate matters, as notaries frequently refuse to open inheritance cases for properties in occupied territories, likely due to potential legal liabilities. This forces heirs to seek court confirmation of ownership, again requiring court fees and proof[8][9]. These legal challenges directly impede the ability of owners to meet the eRecovery program's requirements, which only provides compensation for housing destruction, as assessing damage via satellite images is not feasible[4][6].

Efforts to expand the eRecovery program to other territories, such as Mariupol and Bakhmut, are underway, contingent on funding support. A draft law to this effect is registered in the Parliament and is preparing for a second reading[1][2][4]. Meanwhile, the increased demand for services and housing stock in areas regaining government control is straining resources, as these regions have been severely affected by the conflict[11].

In response to the growing need for technical documentation and cadastral numbers for land plots, legislative amendments have extended the deadline for registering land ownership from January 2025 to January 2028. This extension aims to alleviate the backlog and prevent unregistered land from being considered free and sold by the state[21][26]. These amendments have passed in parliament and await the Presidential signature[26].

In Odesa, the ETC provided temporary internet connectivity services in response to intensified shelling, supporting registration points and tents set up by local authorities. This service, utilizing Remote Site on Vehicle (RSoV) and satellite solutions, ensured all community members were registered by May 9[41][42][43][45]. In Kherson, where medical facilities were destroyed, healthcare workers like nurse Olha Varenyk have adapted by conducting check-ups in modular structures installed in their yards[51][52].

The Mykolaiv region faces additional challenges due to floods that displaced unexploded ordnance (UXO), halting operations in affected areas for up to six months[71][81]. Ukraine's reconstruction, estimated to cost over USD 486 billion, aims to transform the economy to be climate resilient and inclusive, contributing to Europe's growth through innovation and energy security[91][93].

Geographical contexts significantly influence the prioritization of activities, with specific zones established to address varying needs. Context 1 requires emergency activities due to regular attacks, while Context 4 faces extreme limitations in humanitarian access and market functionality[101][102][107]. Monitoring the effectiveness of emergency construction materials and shelter kits distribution involves tracking the number of households, individuals, social facilities, and residential units supported[112].

In Donetska oblast, safety strategies include switching to online formats or mobile brigades for activities, consulting authorities on security, and pre-determining evacuation routes and transit hubs[121][131]. Education Cluster activities in Kharkivska oblast focus on protecting children's right to education amid disruptions, providing mental health support, learning kits, and establishing safe spaces for learning and wellbeing[141][144][145][148].

9.context: It is common for notaries to refuse to open an inheritance case about property located in the temporarily occupied territory, likely due to the potential legal responsibility for such actions which would lie with the respective notary. The problem most often arises with private notaries, which have more discretion than state notaries, in particular in Vinnytsia Oblasts and in Kryvyi Rih City. As a result, the applicants heirs are forced to apply to the court to confirm ownership in the order of inheritance, paying a court fee and bearing the burden of proof. The number of requests for technical documentation and cadastral numbers for plots of land for horticulture has increased rapidly.

52.context: Destroyed hospitals, a lack of medical staff, and daily shelling are the conditions under which healthcare workers in the Kherson and Mykolaiv oblasts work.Ministry of Health nurse Olha Varenyk shows a medical facility in the village of Virivka in Kherson oblast. Now just over 200 people are left here. During the Russian military occupation of the village, the facility was destroyed and looted. Initially, the woman was conducting medical check-ups in her home, but recently a modular structure was installed in her yard, allowing her to see patients there.
52.title: One year after the Kakhovka dam disaster, MSF continues to provide support [EN/UK]

51.context: "A village with one nurseThe destruction of the Kakhovka dam has had a significant impact on the health care system in southern Ukraine, which is also affected by the fighting. Health care workers in the Kherson and Mykolaiv regions work amid poor conditions including destroyed hospitals, a lack of medical staff, and daily shelling.Only 200 people are left in the village of Virivka in Kherson. During the Russian military occupation of the village, its medical facility was destroyed and looted. Ministry of Health nurse Olha Varenyk initially had to conduct medical check-ups in her home, but recently a modular structure was installed in her yard, allowing her to see patients there.
51.title: One year after Ukraine’s Kakhovka dam disaster

61.context: To preserve the lives of the population located in a 5-10 kilometer zone from the border f it is recommended that people be evacuated to safe, prepared places in accordance with the evacuation plans of the hromadas of Sumy, Okhtyrka, Konotop, and Shostka rayons or other oblasts. Voluntary early evacuation of the population from Bilopillia and Vorozhba is also underway. The local authorities are concerned about the growing number of internally displaced persons IDPs in the event of a security situation deteriorating within a 20-30 km zone. With only 11 Collective Centers CCs in Sumy, there is insufficient accommodation for potential IDPs.
61.title: PEOPLE IN NEED 9,151

71.context: Eight HALO minefields in the neighbouring Mykolaiv region located along the Inhulets river were severely impacted by the floods. One of the most pressing issues was the displacement of UXO, a grim legacy of the ongoing conflict in Ukraine. These deadly remnants of war were displaced by the powerful currents and carried to new, often unpredictable locations.BELOW THE SURFACE OF THE WATERSome areas where HALO teams had been working in Mykolaiv oblast were severely impacted by the flooding which potentially contained new explosive threats. As a result, operations in the affected areas ceased for up to six months.
71.title: One Year Since the Kakhovka Dam Destruction

93.context: The macrofinancial assistance meant to keep Ukraine's government functioning cannot finance the recovery as well. In addition to central government funds, a myriad of Western grants and loans need to be tied to individual projects. The innovative systems designed to implement this are up and running but not always used to their full potential.This report provides a snapshot of the economic, societal, and energy-security situation on the ground, capturing key challenges and opportunities for supporting Ukraine's survival and building a more prosperous future. It also explores how the country can meaningfully contribute to Europe's economic growth and strategic autonomy at large through innovation, energy security, decarbonization, and diversified supply chains.
93.title: Reconstructing Ukraine at war: The journey to prosperity starts now

91.context: title: Pragmatically Integrating Sustainability Into the Reconstruction of Ukraine  content: by Samuel Soman.IntroductionAccording to the latest estimates, direct damage to Ukraine in the 2 years since Russia's full- scale invasion has reached USD 155 billion, Kyiv School of Economics, 2024 with economic losses amounting to USD 499 billion World Bank, 2024. Considering an ambitious 10-year plan by the Ukrainian government and the international community, it will cost over USD 486 billion to fund reconstruction efforts World Bank, 2024. Although devastating, this juncture can be a watershed moment for Ukrainian society to "build back better. "Ukraine aims to capitalize upon its reconstruction to transform its economy and society to become climate resilient and inclusive.
91.title: Pragmatically Integrating Sustainability Into the Reconstruction of Ukraine

For example, limited access, proximity to conflict zones, or onset emergencies following attacks can all impact the process. Namely, key response activities support access to wellbeing and learning in safe spaces, learning for school-age children on the move evacuees; access to learning and wellbeing activities for children in safe spaces in Kharkiv city and oblast whose online education might be disrupted by increased missile attacks and damages to civil infrastructure electricity and internet cuts; access to offline learning and wellbeing activities for both displaced and host community children to ensure they keep up with formal schooling and minimize learning losses after their learning was disrupted; support for teachers who might be themselves affected by escalations displaced and face increased workload and challenges in supporting their students.Activities: Provision of MHPSS for children including social-emotional learning and informal education support Distribution of learning kits and electronic devices for learning; Establishment of safe spaces for children to play, and receive wellbeing and learning support  Temporary Learning SpacesDigital Learning Centers; Catch up learning support services for children to regain access to formal learning; Wellbeing support services for teachers.
141.title: Ukraine Education Cluster - Kharkivska oblast (May - July 2024)

clusters.cluster_summary:
On the inaccessible side of the river, Doctors Without Borders was the "sole organization offering medical services and medicines" at that time, highlighting a critical shortage that adversely affected health outcomes. This was exemplified by a patient whose blood sugar was "extremely high and rapidly increasing," with no available medicines from either the paramedic or neighbors to provide assistance[1][4][5][6]. To address these gaps, Doctors Without Borders took proactive measures by purchasing large quantities of water and storage containers for distribution to residents[1][5]. They organized the transport of necessary supplies, including medicine, by boat from the village of Fedorivka, located across the river[2][4]. Volunteers were enlisted to help transport packs containing water, water disinfectants, and medicine kits to the other side by boat[5][6]. Additionally, the team discovered a single unflooded bridge, which enabled them to continue seeing patients on the other side of the river[2][4]. 

Doctors Without Borders continues to operate mobile clinics staffed by a diverse team of doctors, paramedics, nurses, social workers, and psychologists, providing essential medical services and medicines to residents[1][10]. They also transport patients to hospitals in ambulances and support frontline hospitals with medical donations[10]. Despite these efforts, the sources do not specify what additional resources are needed beyond what Doctors Without Borders has already provided or is currently providing.

In a broader context, Ukraine aims to leverage its reconstruction, estimated to cost over USD 486 billion, to transform its economy and society into one that is climate resilient and inclusive[11]. By focusing on innovation, energy security, decarbonization, and diversified supply chains, Ukraine can significantly contribute to Europe's economic growth and strategic autonomy[11][13].

10.context: "About our work in UkraineDoctors Without Borders continues to work near the front lines of Ukraine. Our mobile clinics are staffed by doctors, paramedics, nurses, social workers, and psychologists who provide medical services and medicines to residents of towns and villages in the Kherson, Mykolaiv, Kharkiv, and Donetsk regions. Our teams transport patients to hospitals in our ambulances and support frontline hospitals with medical donations.
10.title: One year after Ukraine’s Kakhovka dam disaster

13.context: The macrofinancial assistance meant to keep Ukraine's government functioning cannot finance the recovery as well. In addition to central government funds, a myriad of Western grants and loans need to be tied to individual projects. The innovative systems designed to implement this are up and running but not always used to their full potential.This report provides a snapshot of the economic, societal, and energy-security situation on the ground, capturing key challenges and opportunities for supporting Ukraine's survival and building a more prosperous future. It also explores how the country can meaningfully contribute to Europe's economic growth and strategic autonomy at large through innovation, energy security, decarbonization, and diversified supply chains.
13.title: Reconstructing Ukraine at war: The journey to prosperity starts now

11.context: title: Pragmatically Integrating Sustainability Into the Reconstruction of Ukraine  content: by Samuel Soman.IntroductionAccording to the latest estimates, direct damage to Ukraine in the 2 years since Russia's full- scale invasion has reached USD 155 billion, Kyiv School of Economics, 2024 with economic losses amounting to USD 499 billion World Bank, 2024. Considering an ambitious 10-year plan by the Ukrainian government and the international community, it will cost over USD 486 billion to fund reconstruction efforts World Bank, 2024. Although devastating, this juncture can be a watershed moment for Ukrainian society to "build back better. "Ukraine aims to capitalize upon its reconstruction to transform its economy and society to become climate resilient and inclusive.
11.title: Pragmatically Integrating Sustainability Into the Reconstruction of Ukraine
