clusters.cluster_id: SDG 16 - Peace, Justice and Strong Institutions
clusters.cluster_summary:
Owners of destroyed housing in temporarily occupied territories of Ukraine face significant legal challenges that hinder their ability to receive compensation through the eRecovery program. A primary issue is the difficulty in property registration due to the fact that most Bureaus of Technical Inventory (BTIs) in these areas were not relocated to government-controlled territories, or were damaged, destroyed, or looted, making it nearly impossible to obtain necessary information for state registration of property rights (SRPR) [3][5][6][21][22][24]. The law mandates that state registrars receive information from BTIs for state registration of rights, but this requirement is difficult to fulfill under current conditions [5][6][21][22]. Owners who acquired property before 2013 face additional hurdles in registering their rights in the SRPR, even if they possess hard copies of title documents, often necessitating a judicial procedure to recognize ownership, which involves court fees and the burden of proof [3][4][6][8][24].

Inheritance issues further complicate matters, as notaries frequently refuse to open inheritance cases for properties in occupied territories, likely due to potential legal liabilities. This forces heirs to seek court confirmation of ownership, again requiring court fees and proof [8][9]. These registration difficulties directly impede an owner's ability to apply for compensation through the eRecovery program, as registration in the SRPR is a prerequisite [4][6][21][23]. The program is limited to providing compensation only for cases of complete destruction, as assessing damage via satellite images is not feasible [4][6]. Plans to expand the program to other territories, including Mariupol and Bakhmut, depend on funding support, with a draft law currently under parliamentary review [1][2][4].

In response to the increased demand for technical documentation and cadastral numbers for horticultural land plots, legislative amendments have been initiated to extend the registration deadline from January 1, 2025, to January 1, 2028. These amendments, passed by parliament and awaiting presidential approval, aim to alleviate the backlog and prevent unregistered land from being sold by the state [11][16].

In Odesa, the Emergency Telecommunications Cluster (ETC) provided temporary internet connectivity from May 7 to 8 in response to intensified shelling, supporting registration points and tents set up by local authorities [31][32]. This service, utilizing Remote Site on Vehicle (RSoV) and satellite solutions, enabled the registration of all community members by May 9 [31][33][35].

In Kherson, healthcare workers face dire conditions, with destroyed hospitals and daily shelling. Nurse Olha Varenyk initially conducted medical check-ups in her home after the local medical facility was destroyed and looted. A modular structure has since been installed in her yard to facilitate patient care [41][42]. The World Health Organization (WHO) emphasizes the urgent need to restore hospitals in Rafah to improve access and functionality [51].

Flooding in the Mykolaiv region has severely impacted eight HALO minefields, displacing unexploded ordnance (UXO) to unpredictable locations, halting operations for up to six months [71][81]. The displacement of UXO poses new explosive threats, complicating efforts to ensure civilian safety.

Organizations like CARE and JurFem advocate for gender equality and the rights of gender-based violence survivors in Ukraine's recovery efforts. They emphasize the importance of including women and marginalized groups in decision-making to create an equitable recovery agenda [91][94]. CARE supports the participation of Ukrainian civil society at the Ukraine Recovery Conference 2024, aiming to integrate gender perspectives throughout the event [93][102][104]. JurFem focuses on developing gender-oriented approaches in government and business, highlighting the need for comprehensive support for gender-based violence survivors [92].

The Ukraine Red Cross Society (URCS), with the support of embedded CashCap experts, has strengthened its role in external coordination forums, notably Cash Working Groups (CWGs), attaining co-chair status. This has enhanced URCS's visibility and legitimacy as a significant cash actor, facilitating partnerships and coordination with the government and other stakeholders [111][112][114][121][122][123][130]. URCS has become the sole partner of the Ministry of Reintegration and Occupied Policy, handling various responsibilities, including registration and payment for displaced persons [125][130].

The Health Resources and Services Availability Monitoring System (HeRAMS) monitors critical health resources and services in Ukraine, identifying gaps and establishing intervention priorities amid ongoing conflict [131][132][138]. The UN documents violations against Ukrainian children, with over 600 killed and 1,420 injured since the escalation of Russia's invasion in February 2022. The UN collaborates with the Ukrainian government to provide necessary care for affected children [141][142][145][147].

In Donetska oblast, strategies to ensure the safety of evacuees and humanitarian workers include switching to online formats or using mobile brigades in risky areas, conducting activities only in safe locations, and consulting authorities on security situations [171]. The regional commission has decided to evacuate families with children from specific areas, coordinating with the Coordination Headquarters for mandatory evacuation under martial law [221][224]. Provisions for the wellbeing and education of evacuated children include online learning and support for teachers, with a focus on mitigating learning losses and addressing the psychological needs of children traumatized by the war [222][223][225][228].

9.context: It is common for notaries to refuse to open an inheritance case about property located in the temporarily occupied territory, likely due to the potential legal responsibility for such actions which would lie with the respective notary. The problem most often arises with private notaries, which have more discretion than state notaries, in particular in Vinnytsia Oblasts and in Kryvyi Rih City. As a result, the applicants heirs are forced to apply to the court to confirm ownership in the order of inheritance, paying a court fee and bearing the burden of proof. The number of requests for technical documentation and cadastral numbers for plots of land for horticulture has increased rapidly.

94.context: title: Ukraine Recovery Conference 2024 in Berlin: Time for Women to Lead in Recovery  content: Bonn, June 7, 2024  In anticipation of the Ukraine Recovery Conference 2024 in Berlin on June 11 and 12, the international humanitarian organization CARE continues to call for all reconstruction and recovery processes to ensure the participation of Ukrainian women and to promote gender equality. So far, the priorities and needs of women have hardly been considered in the discussions on reconstruction. "The meaningful and direct participation of women, girls and marginalized groups in all decision-making processes is key to forming a recovery agenda that is equitable, inclusive, gender-responsive, and truly effective," says Franziska Jrns, CARE Ukraine Deputy Country Director. "We need to protect and ensure equitable access to services they need and opportunities to rebuild their lives.
94.title: Ukraine Recovery Conference 2024 in Berlin: Time for Women to Lead in Recovery

93.context: Survivors also need economic support and need to be included in social programmes. To make sure, these aspects are considered in discussions, decisions, and interventions, this is why we are here at the conference. "CARE welcomes broader participation of Ukrainian civil society including women's rights and women-led organizations at Ukraine Recovery Conference 2024 as well as the intention to integrate gender perspectives throughout the conference.
93.title: Ukraine Recovery Conference 2024 in Berlin: Time for Women to Lead in Recovery

92.context: Support for these local organizations is therefore urgently needed to enable them to have a stronger voice in decision-making on reconstruction and recovery.Women lawyers association JurFem is one of CARE's partner organizations participating in the recovery conference. JurFem works to develop gender-oriented approaches in the work of government and business, with a focus on combating violence against women.Khrystyna Kit, Chairwoman of JurFem, says: "Without a gender component, a just recovery is not possible. A key question is how to strengthen the rights of gender-based violence survivors in recovery. Psychological and medical support is critical but not enough.
92.title: Ukraine Recovery Conference 2024 in Berlin: Time for Women to Lead in Recovery

91.context: "Gender equality has received very little attention in the previous two Ukraine Recovery Conferences in Lugano in 2022 and in London in 2023. It has also been largely absent from the various recovery and reconstruction plans that have been formulated by donor governments and international organizations. But Ukrainian women's rights and women-led organizations continue to drive efforts to meet the needs of the most vulnerable groups and provide vital assistance to survivors of gender-based violence. They are advocating for the rights of women and girls and are essential to increase the participation of those groups in processes and decisions that affect them now and will continue to impact them after the war.
91.title: Ukraine Recovery Conference 2024 in Berlin: Time for Women to Lead in Recovery

122.context: title: CashCap Support to Red CrossRed Crescent National Societies Pilot Review  content: Over the past two years NORCAP's CashCap programme in collaboration with British Red Cross, invested efforts in an initiative to test whether NORCAPCashCap's expertise in coordination, facilitating multistakeholder collaboration processes, capacity-strengthening, policy influence and advocacy for quality Cash and Voucher Assistance CVA adds value to ongoing system-wide localisation efforts, when placed strategically in a mentoring role and embedded within a local organisation over a long period of time. Pilots, both over a year long, took place in Ukraine and in Syria  with CashCap expertise embedded within Red CrossRed Crescent National Societies in Ukraine and in Syria. Both NORCAP and BRC made a commitment to documenting and sharing learning from this initiative  to inform ongoing system-wide push towards locally-led response. An external review of both pilots was commissioned in late 2023.
122.title: CashCap Support to Red Cross/Red Crescent National Societies Pilot Review

Hence, this analysis is not final and was produced solely for the purpose of informing operations.MethodologyThe Health Resources and Services Availability Monitoring System HeRAMS is a system dedicated to monitoring the availability of critical health resources and services, thus playing a crucial role in identifying existing gaps and establishing intervention priorities. HeRAMS aims to provide decision-makers and health stakeholders with vital, up-to-date information.HeRAMS was launched in Ukraine by the World Health Organization WHO Country Office in Ukraine and the Ministry of Health MOH in November 2022. Since its initiation, data has been consistently collected and updated by designated representatives at both the Departments of Health and health facility levels, focusing on all public health facilities that are accessible1 .Acknowledging potential factors that might compromise data quality, the HeRAMS team at WHO CO opted to undertake data verification.

This current report provides a high-level summary of the up-to-date status of health facilities within Ukraine, focusing on the availability of essential services and the challenges impeding access to these services. 181.context: title: Nuclear Safety, Security and Safeguards in Ukraine - Report by the Director General GOV20249  content: Summary The Board of Governors, in its resolutions GOV202217, GOV202258 and GOV202271, requested the Director General to continue to closely monitor the situation regarding nuclear safety, security and safeguards in Ukraine and regularly report formally to the Board of Governors on these matters. This report provides a summary of the situation in Ukraine regarding nuclear safety, security and safeguards. It covers the period from 15 November 2023 to 23 February 2024 and is based on information made available to the Agency, and verified by the Agency, during this period. This report covers the progress made by the Agency in responding to Ukraine's requests to provide technical support and assistance in re-establishing, as appropriate, a sound nuclear safety and security regime at its nuclear facilities and in activities involving radioactive sources.

228.context: Education Cluster activities in Kharkivska oblast aim at ensuring protecting children's wellbeing in the face of displacement, whilst ensuring children's right to education is protected amid the disruptions caused by the recent escalation of hostilities. clusters.cluster_summary:
In the Mykolaiv region, eight HALO minefields were severely impacted by floods, leading to the displacement of unexploded ordnance (UXO) and halting operations in the affected areas for up to six months[1]. Despite this disruption, there is no information on how humanitarian organizations are coordinating with HALO teams to resume these operations.

Amidst these challenges, Ukraine is focusing on its reconstruction efforts, which are estimated to cost over USD 486 billion[11]. The country aims to transform its economy and society to become climate resilient and inclusive, contributing to Europe's economic growth and strategic autonomy through innovation, energy security, decarbonization, and diversified supply chains[11][13].

In parallel, the Ukraine Red Cross Society (URCS) has been significantly bolstered by the embedding of CashCap experts, who have effectively positioned URCS in external coordination forums, notably Cash Working Groups (CWGs)[22]. Through the leadership and training efforts of these experts, URCS attained co-chair status in the CWG, enhancing its visibility among donors and international organizations and granting it legitimacy as a major cash actor[21][24]. This status allowed URCS to take on more significant roles in external coordination structures[24].

The CashCap experts played a crucial role in facilitating URCS's partnerships and coordination with the government and other stakeholders, providing expertise in coordination, multistakeholder collaboration, capacity-strengthening, policy influence, and advocacy for quality Cash and Voucher Assistance (CVA)[31][32]. They enhanced CVA skills within URCS, contributed to documentation development, and improved information management[31][38]. This support helped URCS gain a deeper understanding of its role with the government[33].

As a result, URCS became the sole partner of the Ministry of Reintegration and Occupied Policy since September 2022, managing registration, payment, Post-Distribution Monitoring (PDM), and Community Engagement and Accountability (CEA)[35]. Memoranda of Understanding (MOUs) were established with the government, and URCS implemented a no-regret cash in envelope for 270,000 recipients for the Ministry[35][40]. Additionally, URCS handled 100,000 recipients per month for host community members hosting Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs)[35]. The experts' contributions significantly enhanced the visibility and empowerment of URCS[33].

1.context: Eight HALO minefields in the neighbouring Mykolaiv region located along the Inhulets river were severely impacted by the floods. One of the most pressing issues was the displacement of UXO, a grim legacy of the ongoing conflict in Ukraine. These deadly remnants of war were displaced by the powerful currents and carried to new, often unpredictable locations.BELOW THE SURFACE OF THE WATERSome areas where HALO teams had been working in Mykolaiv oblast were severely impacted by the flooding which potentially contained new explosive threats. As a result, operations in the affected areas ceased for up to six months.
1.title: One Year Since the Kakhovka Dam Destruction

13.context: The macrofinancial assistance meant to keep Ukraine's government functioning cannot finance the recovery as well. In addition to central government funds, a myriad of Western grants and loans need to be tied to individual projects. The innovative systems designed to implement this are up and running but not always used to their full potential.This report provides a snapshot of the economic, societal, and energy-security situation on the ground, capturing key challenges and opportunities for supporting Ukraine's survival and building a more prosperous future. It also explores how the country can meaningfully contribute to Europe's economic growth and strategic autonomy at large through innovation, energy security, decarbonization, and diversified supply chains.
13.title: Reconstructing Ukraine at war: The journey to prosperity starts now

11.context: title: Pragmatically Integrating Sustainability Into the Reconstruction of Ukraine  content: by Samuel Soman.IntroductionAccording to the latest estimates, direct damage to Ukraine in the 2 years since Russia's full- scale invasion has reached USD 155 billion, Kyiv School of Economics, 2024 with economic losses amounting to USD 499 billion World Bank, 2024. Considering an ambitious 10-year plan by the Ukrainian government and the international community, it will cost over USD 486 billion to fund reconstruction efforts World Bank, 2024. Although devastating, this juncture can be a watershed moment for Ukrainian society to "build back better. "Ukraine aims to capitalize upon its reconstruction to transform its economy and society to become climate resilient and inclusive.
11.title: Pragmatically Integrating Sustainability Into the Reconstruction of Ukraine

32.context: title: CashCap Support to Red CrossRed Crescent National Societies Pilot Review  content: Over the past two years NORCAP's CashCap programme in collaboration with British Red Cross, invested efforts in an initiative to test whether NORCAPCashCap's expertise in coordination, facilitating multistakeholder collaboration processes, capacity-strengthening, policy influence and advocacy for quality Cash and Voucher Assistance CVA adds value to ongoing system-wide localisation efforts, when placed strategically in a mentoring role and embedded within a local organisation over a long period of time. Pilots, both over a year long, took place in Ukraine and in Syria  with CashCap expertise embedded within Red CrossRed Crescent National Societies in Ukraine and in Syria. Both NORCAP and BRC made a commitment to documenting and sharing learning from this initiative  to inform ongoing system-wide push towards locally-led response. An external review of both pilots was commissioned in late 2023.
32.title: CashCap Support to Red Cross/Red Crescent National Societies Pilot Review
